column5: WE ALSO PROVIDE GRANTS TO INDIVIDUALS THROUGH THE COMMUNITY SHARING FUND AND J.C. AND L.A. DUKE EMPLOYEES' ASSISTANCE FUND. THE COMMUNITY SHARING FUND PROVIDES SMALL GRANTS TO HELP INDIVIDUALS AND FAMILIES WEATHER A TEMPORARY SETBACK AND KEEP IT FROM BECOMING A MAJOR CRISIS. GRANTS HAVE BEEN USED TO HELP MAINTAIN TRANSPORTATION TO A JOB, COVER RENT OR PAY FOR CHILDCARE. THROUGH A NETWORK OF SOCIAL WORKERS, INDIVIDUALS CAN ACCESS THE FUND WHEN ALL OTHER FORMS OF EMERGENCY ASSISTANCE HAVE BEEN EXHAUSTED. 1,653 GRANTS WERE MADE FROM THE COMMUNITY SHARING FUND DURING 2015.THE DUKE FUND PROVIDES ASSISTANCE TO 3M EMPLOYEES WHO HAVE EXPERIENCED A CATASTROPHIC ILLNESS OR ACCIDENT. GRANTS HELP EMPLOYEES REGAIN SELF-SUFFICIENCY AND RETURN TO THE WORKPLACE. SUPPORT IS DESIGNED TO HELP EMPLOYEES THROUGH A TRANSITION AND IS NOT INDEFINITE. 42 GRANTS WERE MADE FROM THE DUKE FUND DURING 2015.

column6: WATERSHED CONSERVATION PROGRAM: THE WESTERN PENNSYLVANIA CONSERVANCY'S WATERSHED CONSERVATION PROGRAM PROTECTS AND RESTORES OUR REGION'S RIVERS AND STREAMS FOR THE LONG-TERM BENEFIT OF PEOPLE AND WILDLIFE. WE PROVIDE COMPREHENSIVE ASSISTANCE TO COMMUNITIES AND LOCAL WATERSHED GROUPS, HELPING WITH PROJECT IDENTIFICATION, IMPLEMENTATION AND PROJECT MANAGEMENT. WE ALSO PARTNER WITH INDIVIDUAL LANDOWNERS AND BUSINESSES TO HELP THEM IMPROVE WATER QUALITY AND PROTECT THE ENVIRONMENT ON THEIR PROPERTIES. WESTERN PENNSYLVANIA CONSERVANCY HAS PROTECTED OR RESTORED 3,000 MILES OF RIVERS AND STREAMS.

All other projects Healthy Waters: Maine's rivers, lakes, and streams are among our state's most precious and celebrated natural resources. For the third year in a row, NRCM's public education, outreach, and citizen engagement campaign (which we began in 2012) resulted in the Maine Legislature rejecting weak mining rules written by the Maine Department of Environmental Protection (DEP). The proposed rules did not protect Maine's waterways or communities from "acid mine drainage"- a toxic soup of sulfuric acid and heavy metals that results from this type of mining, and can devastate water quality, kill aquatic creatures, and destroy landscapes. NRCM is a founding partner of the Penobscot River Restoration Trust (PRRT). In 2015, PRRT completed construction of a state-of-the-art fish bypass at the Howland Dam on the Piscatiquis River, a major tributary to the Penobscot. Water began flowing through the bypass on September 28, 2015. This final phase of the PRRT project followed the removal of the Veazie Dam (the lowermost barrier to fish passage on the river) in 2013 and the Great Works Dam in 2012. We celebrate PRRT's visionary approach to reconnect endangered Atlantic salmon, shortnose sturgeon, American shad, alewife and seven other native sea-run fish to 1,000 miles of vital spawning habitat in the watershed, without losing an important source of indigenous power generation. The PRRT initiative will result in large-scale ecological, cultural, recreational, and economic benefits throughout the Penobscot watershed. We will continue to measure these benefits in the years to come. Forests & Wildlife: The North Woods of Maine is nationally recognized as the largest undeveloped forest east of the Mississippi River. In 2015, NRCM continued our campaign (launched in 2012) to build community, business, and citizen demand for a proposed new national park and national recreation area along the East Branch of the Penobscot River in the heart of the North Woods. We met with hundreds of opinion leaders, sportsmen, business owners, and organizations; hosted outdoor recreation events on the land; added to our list of endorsements by securing support from the Bangor City Council and the Bangor Daily News, the region's leading newspaper; and gathered over 23,850 names on a petition in support of the park proposal. Currently, NRCM is urging President Obama to use his authority under the 1906 Antiquities Act to designate the area as a new National Monument. Simultaneously, NRCM worked in coalition with other conservation groups to secure the release of $11.5 million in voter-approved conservation bond funds for the Land for Maine's Future (LMF), the state program that conserves lands of exceptional natural or recreational value. We also worked to protect Maine's forests from attempts to increase logging on public lands to unsustainable levels and reduce funding for land conservation programs. Sustainable Maine: NRCM has a long history of educating the public about the hazardous chemicals found in items common to our homes, schools, and workplaces, and has helped Maine phase out toxic chemicals in consumer products and create landmark recycling programs for products that pose a risk to our environment and public health. Now, we offer education and hands-on training to communities seeking ways to reduce waste and toxics in the environment, increase participation in recycling and organic composting, and boost the production and use of clean and efficient energy. In 2015, NRCM built on the initial success of plastic bag and foam packaging ordinances we helped Portland, Maine adopt and implement. We worked with York, Falmouth, and South Portland to adopt ordinances to put a fee on single-use plastic bags, and helped citizens in Kennebunk, Brunswick, Topsham, and Freeport launch similar campaigns. We also created our Sustainable Maine Communities Toolkits, online resources featuring topics such as reusable bags, foam packaging, cigarette litter prevention, pay-as-you-throw trash policies, pesticide bans, community solar projects, and community gardens.

column4: STAKEHOLDER ENGAGEMENT AND COMMUNICATION:THE GOAL OF NEEA'S STAKEHOLDER ENGAGEMENT AND COMMUNICATION TEAM IS TO FACILITATE AND ADVANCE REGIONAL COLLABORATION BETWEEN NEEA AND ITS FUNDERS AND STAKEHOLDERS. IN 2015, NEEA STAFF: -DELIVERED THE 6TH ANNUAL EFFICIENCY EXCHANGE CONFERENCE TO FACILITATE REGIONAL COLLABORATION ON ENERGY EFFICIENCY OPPORTUNITIES AND SHARE SUCCESS STORIES AND BEST PRACTICES. -HOSTED SUCCESSFUL CONDUITED EDUCATION SERIES ON MARKET TRANSFORMATION, GARNERING MORE THAN 75 PARTICIPANTS AND 500 VIEWS AND COMMENTS. -CONVENED CHIEF EXECUTIVE OFFICERS FROM UTILITIES AND KEY REGIONAL ENERGY EFFICIENCY GROUPS (NATURAL RESOURCES DEFENSE COUNCIL, NW ENERGY COALITION, NORTHWEST POWER AND CONSERVATION COUNCIL, AND OTHERS) TO DISCUSS THE FUTURE OF ENERGY EFFICIENCY IN THE REGION AT THE SECOND ANNUAL NORTHWEST ENERGY EFFICIENCY LEADERSHIP MEETING. -ORGANIZED AND FACILITATED QUARTERLY NEEA SECTOR ADVISORY COMMITTEE MEETINGS TO ENSURE REGIONAL PARTICIPATION IN NEEA MARKET TRANSFORMATION PROGRAMS.

column6: AIR, WATER & PUBLIC HEALTH: WE WORKED WITH CHARLESTON COUNTY TO SET TIMELINE TO RETROFIT A LANE ON THE ASHLEY RIVER BRIDGE FOR USE BY PEOPLE WALKING AND BIKING. AT A PUBLIC INFORMATION SESSION, THE MAJORITY OF THE 400 ATTENDEES WERE IN FAVOR OF THE LANE CONVERSION, AND THE EXCITEMENT WAS PALPABLE. CHARLESTON COUNTY WILL "TEST" THE LANE CONVERSION IN THE MONTHS TO COME. IN ADDITION, CONSERVATION LEAGUE STAFF HAS WORKED FOR MONTHS TO REVIVE THE SHELVED JAMES ISLAND CONNECTOR RETROFIT STUDY, BOTH WITH THE PUBLIC AND CITY COUNCIL. THESE EFFORTS AND CONSEQUENT NEW INQUIRIES RESULTED IN A POSITIVE EDITORIAL FROM THE POST AND COURIER SUPPORTING BOTH THE ASHLEY RIVER BRIDGE AND THE JAMES ISLAND CONNECTOR RETROFITS FOR PEOPLE ON BIKES. WE ALSO WORKED WITH PARTNERS AND CITIZEN GROUPS TO PASS THE FIRST PLASTIC BAG BAN IN THE STATE ON ISLE OF PALMS.

column4: VOTER EDUCATION PROGRAM - The goal of the Voter Education Program is to identify voters who care about environmental protection in Washington State and to engage them in non-partisan civic action. This is accomplished through innovation, research and education.ENVIRONMENTAL PRIORITIES - The goal of the Environmental Priorities Coalition is to bring together over twenty environmental organizations across Washington State to build a strong economy that provides everyone with the opportunity to prosper and a clean, healthy and safe environment for ourselves and our children. Each year the Coalition chooses a select number of priorities to advance in the State Capitol that will help to achieve these goals.

column6: HEALTHY BABIES - THE NURSE-FAMILY PARTNERSHIP (NFP) USES PROFESSIONAL NURSES TO TARGET FIRST-TIME, LOW-INCOME PREGNANT WOMEN WHO ARE NO MORE THAN 28 WEEKS PREGNANT TO HELP THEM HAVE A HEALTHY PREGNANCY AND THEN OFFER THEM EDUCATION AND SUPPORT THROUGH THE CHILD'S SECOND BIRTHDAY. IN 2015, 77% OF BABIES BORN IN THE PROGRAM HAD A HEALTH BIRTH WEIGHT AND 87% WERE AT FULL GESTATIONAL AGE. 93% OF INFANTS IN THE PROGRAM HAD UP-TO-DATE IMMUNIZATIONS. SMART START/HEALTHY FAMILIES AMERICA (HFA) USES NURSES AND SOCIAL WORKERS AS HOME VISITORS TO PROVIDE PARENTS AN OPPORTUNITY TO GET THE EDUCATION AND SUPPORT THEY NEED AT THE TIME THEIR BABY IS BORN, UNTIL THEIR CHILD TURNS THREE. SMART START/HFA CAN SERVE FIRST TIME MOMS WHO ARE MORE THAN 28-WEEKS PREGNANT OR HAVE A NEWBORN YOUNGER THAN THREE MONTHS, AS WELL AS MOMS FOR WHOM THIS IS NOT A FIRST PREGNANCY. IN 2015, 89% OF BABIES BORN HAD A HEALTHY WEIGHT AND 94% WERE BORN AT FULL GESTATIONAL AGE.

FAMILY RESOURCES - CHILD, ELDER, AND RESPITE CARE REFERRAL SERVICES HELP FAMILIES ACCESS CARE. IN 2015, THE HELPLINE RECEIVED OVER 9,200 REQUESTS FOR INFORMATION. GRAND TIME OFF PROVIDES RESPITE FOR OLDER RELATIVES RAISING FAMILY MEMBERS' CHILDREN. IN 2015, WE RESPONDED TO 375 CALLS RELATED TO GRAND TIME OFF.KINSHIP NAVIGATOR IS A FREE SERVICE FOR FAMILIES WHO ARE CARING FOR OTHER RELATIVE'S CHILDREN. A NAVIGATOR SPEAKS WITH THE FAMILY TO DETERMINE NEEDS AND PROVIDE INFORMATION AND REFERRALS. IN 2015, CFF SERVED 25 FAMILIES. COMMUNITY SCHOOLS ARE PARTNERSHIPS BETWEEN CFF & THREE DELAWARE SCHOOL DISTRICTS WITH TARGETED ELEMENTARY AND/OR MIDDLE SCHOOLS WITH HIGH RATES OF LOW-INCOME STUDENTS. A COMMUNITY SCHOOL IS AN EDUCATIONAL INSTITUTION THAT COMBINES THE BEST EDUCATIONAL PRACTICES OF A QUALITY SCHOOL WITH A WIDE RANGE OF VITAL IN-HOUSE HEALTH AND SOCIAL SERVICES TO ENSURE THAT CHILDREN ARE PHYSICALLY, EMOTIONALLY, AND SOCIALLY PREPARED TO LEARN. IN 2015, THE COMMUNITY SCHOOLS MADE MORE THAN 10,000 CONTACTS WITH PARENTS, YOUTH, AND COMMUNITY MEMBERS (DUPLICATED COUNT).
SUPPORTING OLDER ADULTS - GRAND TIME OFF PROVIDES RESPITE FOR OLDER RELATIVES RAISING FAMILY MEMBERS' CHILDREN. IN 2015, 100% OF USERS REPORTED THAT THE SERVICE MET THEIR NEEDS.

WORKPLACE SUPPORT - RISE UP HELPS THOSE MOVING FROM WELFARE TO WORK IN KENT AND SUSSEX COUNTIES SUCCESS IN EMPLOYMENT. IN 2015, 80% OF INDIVIDUALS IN THE PROGRAM MET PARTICIPATION REQUIREMENTS FOR THREE CONSECUTIVE TWELVE-WEEK PERIODS. 75% OF CLIENTS REPORTED BEING ENGAGED IN SOME TYPE OF EMPLOYMENT OR EDUCATION AT CASE CLOSING.JUST-IN-TIME CARE (JITC) IS A COMPREHENSIVE BACK-UP DEPENDENT CARE PROGRAM OFFERED BY CORPORATIONS ACROSS THE U.S. AS AN EMPLOYEE BENEFIT. EMPLOYEES WHO USED JITC SAVED 8,654WORK DAYS WERE SAVED BY PARENTS WHO USED JITC IN 2015, AND 99% INDICATED THAT THEY WERE ABLE TO GET TO WORK BECAUSE OF THE PROGRAM.

PROGRAM QUALITY IMPROVEMENT (PQI) - THE QUALITY IMPROVEMENT PROCESS IS DESIGNED TO ASSESS THE QUALITY OF CUSTOMER SERVICES, ASSURE UTILIZATION AND CONTRACT GOAL ATTAINMENT, AND TO REFINE PROGRAMS BASED UPON WHAT HAS BEEN LEARNED. INDIVIDUAL-LEVEL DATA IS ENTERED INTO THE EVOLV AND ETO DATA SYSTEMS, WHICH IS USED FOR INDIVIDUAL DATA TRACKING AS WELL AS AGGREGATED OUTPUT FOR OUTCOMES MANAGEMENT. THE ORGANIZATION HAS A STATEWIDE OUTCOMES COMMITTEE THAT MEETS QUARTERLY TO REVIEW DATA FROM ALL AGENCY PROGRAMS. EACH DEPARTMENT/UNIT AND THE OUTCOMES COMMITTEE REPORT TO THE AGENCY-WIDE PQI COMMITTEE COMPOSED OF REPRESENTATIVES OF PROGRAM AND OPERATIONAL DEPARTMENTS, ON A QUARTERLY BASIS. BOTH COMMITTEES PROVIDE REGULAR REPORTS TO THE CHILDREN & FAMILIES FIRST LEADERSHIP TEAM AND THE BOARD OF DIRECTORS.

PROVIDED EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMS TO OVER 400 WOMEN AT THE ALBION CORRECTIONAL FACILITY.

column5: EDUCATION DEPARTMENTTHE EDUCATION DEPARTMENT STRIVES TO PROMOTE A BETTER UNDERSTANDING OF IMMIGRANTS AND IMMIGRATION BY PROVIDING EDUCATIONAL RESOURCES THAT INSPIRE THOUGHTFUL DIALOGUE, CREATIVE TEACHING AND CRITICAL THINKING. DEDICATED TO THE AMERICAN VALUES OF FAIRNESS, SOCIAL JUSTICE AND RESPECT FOR ALL PEOPLE, THE EDUCATION DEPARTMENT IS COMMITTED TO MAKING IMMIGRATION AN "EVERYBODY ISSUE". THE EDUCATION DEPARTMENT ALSO HIGHLIGHTS THE POSITIVE CONTRIBUTIONS IMMIGRANTS HAVE MADE AND CONTINUE TO MAKE TO AMERICAN SOCIETY THROUGH ITS PROGRAMMATIC WORK. THROUGH EDUCATOR WORKSHOPS, AN ANNUAL CREATIVE WRITING CONTEST, RESOURCES FOR TEACHERS CREATED BY TEACHERS AND COMMUNITY GRANTS, THE EDUCATION DEPARTMENT BRINGS THE DISCUSSION OF IMMIGRATION TO COMMUNITIES ACROSS THE NATION.

column4: COMMUNICATIONS:THE COMMUNICATIONS TEAM AT THE COUNCIL IS WORKING TO DRIVE A RATIONAL CONVERSATION ABOUT IMMIGRATION IN THE UNITED STATES. THE COMMUNICATIONS TEAM SUPPORTS THE PROGRAMS IN PLANNING AND EXECUTING A WIDE RANGE OF PUBLICATIONS AND OUTREACH ACTIVITIES WITH THE GOAL OF REACHING TARGET AUDIENCES. THE TEAM ALSO RUNS OUR SOCIAL MEDIA COMPONENTS INCLUDING THE HIGHLY SUCCESSFUL IMMIGRATION BLOG WWW.IMMIGRATIONIMPACT.ORG

column5: ZOO VISITOR SERVICES - THE ZOO INCURS EXPENSES RELATED TO THE OPERATION AND MANAGEMENT OF ITS FOOD SERVICE, GIFT SHOP, VISITOR EXPERIENCES AND ADMISSION SALES.

column6: RETAIL/LICENSED PRODUCTS - HISTORIC CHARLESTON FOUNDATION BEGAN ITS LICENSED PRODUCTS PROGRAM IN 1972 AS AN INNOVATIVE WAY TO EXTEND THE FOUNDATION'S RESTORATION AND PRESERVATION EFFORTS BEYOND HISTORIC ARCHITECTURE AND INTERIORS TO CHARLESTON'S MATERIAL CULTURE AS WELL. THE PROGRAM STRIVES TO KEEP CHARLESTON DESIGNS ALIVE AND MAKE THOSE DESIGNS AVAILABLE TO A BROAD AUDIENCE. ITEMS SELECTED FOR INCLUSION ARE THOSE WHOSE ORIGINS ARE STEEPED IN CHARLESTON'S HISTORY, CULTURE, DECORATIVE ARTS AND ARCHITECTURE.THE LICENSED PRODUCTS OF HISTORIC CHARLESTON FOUNDATION RANGE FROM FURNITURE, CHINA, MIRRORS, JEWELRY, PORCELAIN, DECORATIVE ACCESSORIES AND HISTORIC PAINT COLORS. MANY OF THE ORIGINAL OBJECTS, WHICH ARE REPRODUCED OR ARE USED FOR INSPIRATION, MAY BE SEEN IN THE HISTORIC MUSEUM HOUSE COLLECTIONS OF HISTORIC CHARLESTON FOUNDATION AND OTHER MUSEUM COLLECTIONS IN CHARLESTON.THE SHOPS OF HISTORIC CHARLESTON FOUNDATION SHOWCASES THE LICENSED PRODUCTS OF THE FOUNDATION AS WELL AS AN EXTENSIVE SELECTION OF BOOKS ON CHARLESTON HISTORY, ARCHITECTURE, GARDENS AND CULTURE. WITHIN THE SHOPS OF HISTORIC CHARLESTON FOUNDATION IS THE FRANCES R. EDMUNDS BOOKSTORE, PROVIDING THE MOST COMPREHENSIVE SELECTION OF BOOKS ON CHARLESTON AND LOWCOUNTRY HISTORY IN THE CITY. IN ADDITION, THE SHOPS INCLUDE A WIDE RANGE OF DECORATIVE ARTS AND GIFT ITEMS, INCLUDING CHINA; JEWELRY; FORMAL, CASUAL AND GARDEN FURNITURE; LAMPS; MIRRORS AND A PALETTE OF HISTORICAL PAINT COLORS INSPIRED BY RESIDENCES IN CHARLESTON'S OLD & HISTORIC DISTRICT, AS WELL AS THE RURAL LOWCOUNTRY SEA ISLANDS.THE MARKET SHOP OF HISTORIC CHARLESTON, WHICH OPENED IN THE SUMMER OF 2011, IS THE ANCHOR SHOP IN THE GREAT HALL OF THE HISTORIC CHARLESTON CITY MARKET. WITH DISPLAYS THAT DEMONSTRATE THE FOUNDATION'S MISSION AND A SELECTION OF THE ITEMS FOUND IN THE MAIN RETAIL LOCATION, THE SHOP ALLOWS THE FOUNDATION TO REACH A WIDER AUDIENCE WITH THE MILLIONS OF ANNUAL VISITORS WHO GO THROUGH THE MARKET EACH YEAR.

WITH AN INITIAL INVESTMENT OF $500,000 FROM THE KRESGE FOUNDATION IN EARLY 2010, CMF LAUNCHED THE COMMUNITY FOUNDATION CHALLENGE GRANT TO ENCOURAGE MICHIGAN COMMUNITY FOUNDATIONS TO EXPAND, ENHANCE, STRENGTHEN AND SUSTAIN THEIR LOCAL COLLEGE ACCESS PARTNERSHIPS. CMF BELIEVES THAT COMMUNITY FOUNDATIONS ARE IDEAL CANDIDATES TO SUPPORT LOCAL COLLEGE ACCESS PROGRAMS BECAUSE OF THEIR LONG-STANDING SUPPORT OF COLLEGE SCHOLARSHIPS, THEIR LEADERSHIP AND COMMITMENT TO MCAN EFFORTS, AND THEIR POSITION AS VITAL LEADERS IN MICHIGAN'S COMMUNITIES. THE PURPOSE OF THE COMMUNITY FOUNDATION CHALLENGE GRANT INITIATIVE IS TO LEVERAGE LOCAL PRIVATE INVESTMENT TO ENGAGE AND SUSTAIN COLLEGE ACCESS PARTNERSHIPS, THEREBY INCREASING THE COLLEGE-GOING RATE AND CULTURE IN MICHIGAN.

column6: AS A MEMBERSHIP ASSOCIATION OF FOUNDATIONS & CORPORATE GIVING PROGRAMS CMF PROVIDES RESOURCES TO MEMBERS THROUGH ITS WEBSITE, SEMINARS, CONFERENCES AND PUBLICATIONS. CMF IS ACTIVELY INVOLVED IN ADVOCACY ON BEHALF OF FOUNDATIONS & CORPORATE GIVING PROGRAMS REGARDING LEGISLATIVE & REGULATORY ISSUES THAT AFFECT CHARITABLE GIVING & THE NONPROFIT SECTOR.

THE PRIMARY PROGRAM OFFERINGS NOT INCLUDED IN HEALTH & WELLNESS, CHILD CARE, AND AQUATICS ARE ADULT AND YOUTH SPORTS, AND PERSONAL TRAINING. IN 2015, 9,875 YOUTH PARTICIPATED IN SPORTS PROGRAMS WHERE THEY LEARNED SELF CONFIDENCE, TEAMWORK, SKILLS AND CHARACTER VALUES OF CARING, HONESTY, RESPECT, RESPONSIBILITY AND FAITH. THE YMCA ALSO PROVIDES THE FIRST TEE PROGRAM FOR OUR COMMUNITY. OVER 24,000 YOUTH HAVE LEARNED LIFE SKILLS THROUGH THE GAME OF GOLF.

column4: TO PROVIDE CARE AND TREATMENT FOR PERSONS IN GRANBURY AND HOOD COUNTY WHO NEED EMERGENCY MEDICAL SERVICES WITHOUT REGUARD TO AGE, SEX, RACE, COLOR, RELIGION, NATION ORGIN, OR EMOTIONAL STATUS. SAID ORGANIZATION IS ORGANIZED EXCLUSIVELY FOR CHARITABLE, RELIGIOUS, EDUCATIONAL AND SCIENTIFIC PRUPOSES, INCLUDING, FOR SUCH PURPOSE, THAT MAKING OF DISTRIBUTIONS TO ORGANIZATIONS THAT QUALIFY AS EXEMPT ORGANIZATIONS UNDER SECTION 501C(3) OF THE INTERNAL REVENUE CODE, OR CORRESPONDING SECTION OF ANY FUTURE FEDERAL TAX CODE.

column5: COMMUNITY SERVICE DEPARTMENT: RVCP PROVIDES A COMMUNITY SERVICE PROGRAM WHICH PLACES AND MONITORS ROCK COUNTY COMMUNITY SERVICE FOR ADULTS IN ROCK COUNTY. THIS PROGRAM IS FUNDED BY THE ROCK COUNTY PUBLIC SAFETY AND JUSTICE COMMITTEE. THIS PROGRAM MONITORS CLIENTS SENTENCED TO COMMUNITY SERVICE IN LIEU OF FINES OR AS A CONDITION OF PROBATION. ----- OPERATING WHILE INTOXICATED (OWI): RVCP PROVIDES OPERATING WHILE INTOXICATED CASE MANAGEMENT AND DRUG TESTING SERVICES FOR THOSE CLIENTS REFERRED FROM THE ROCK COUNTY COURT SYSTEM. ----- CRISIS (CRS): RVCP PROVIDES CRISIS STABILIZATION SERVICES TO CLIENTS FOR THE PURPOSE OF REDUCING MENTAL HEALTH SYMPTOMS TO PREVENT THE NEED FOR INPATIENT HOSPITALIZATION. CLIENTS ARE REFERRED FROM THE ROCK COUNTY HUMAN SERVICES DEPARTMENT.

column6: CONTRACT INCOME: GOODWILL OPERATES A MICRO-ENTERPRISE PROGRAM TO PROVIDE ASPIRING SMALL BUSINESS OWNERS WITH THE SKILLS THEY NEED TO SUCCEED AS ENTREPRENEURS & BECOME MORE INDEPENDENT. GOODWILL'S JOBLINK CENTERS HELP PEOPLE WITH EMPLOYMENT, SKILLS TRAINING AND FAMILY STRENGTHENING TRAINING. THE ORGANIZATION ALSO PROVIDES EMPLOYMENT AND EMPLOYMENT SERVICES TO ADULTS WITH DISABILITIES WHO ARE SEEKING OPPORTUNITIES TO OBTAIN INDEPENDENCE.

column5: OTHER SERVICES CONSISTS PRIMARILY OF SERVICES PROVIDED TO DISABLED OR DISADVANTAGED CITIZENS WITHIN THE COMMUNITY IN AREAS OF FAMILY SERVICES AND AT RISK YOUTH TRAINING.
